title: Mother of the bride hooked up with groom's best friend at their wedding
text:
"I don’t know how long I stood there, gaping with my mouth open."

Some of the most memorable moments of your life that's for sure!

I didn’t grow up with a strong sense of the concept of marriage.

The daughter of a single mother who had me when she was 20, I never knew my father, and my mum was single for most of my childhood.

She dated, sure, but there wasn’t anybody significant that stayed around for more than a year or two. Mum swore she liked it that way, and said she couldn’t think of anything worse than having to live with any man.

So either because of that, or despite it, getting married was always high on my priority list.

I could see how tough it was on mum parenting my older brother and me on her own – we were both a handful, and I know we caused her massive headaches when we were teenagers. From a young age I craved a family unit that included a stable partner.

So when I met Steve* when I was 25, it wasn’t long before I started fantasising setting up a life together. Steve was 10 years older than me, and had a responsible and nurturing element to his personality that I was drawn to.

There's nice wedding surprises and then there's THIS! Source: iStock

He made me feel safe, and he made me feel like part of a team

I knew I wanted to have a family with him, and when he asked me to marry him after two years of dating, I didn’t even have to think before saying yes.

Being halfway between my age and my mother’s, Steve got along well with Mum. He liked her and she liked him – and we often included her when we socialised. Having raised her children when she was practically still a child herself, my mum was discovering a whole new social life in her forties, and she was still incredibly attractive.

Steve’s friends would flirt up a storm whenever Mum came out with us. His best mate Dan* particularly used to give Mum the eye and would always tell her she looked hot, but it never occurred to me to worry. Dan had a girlfriend and he was a loyal guy.

Things never got out of hand until the day of our wedding...

As luck would have it, Dan’s girlfriend had broken up with him about two weeks before the wedding, and he’d been absolutely gutted.

We’d all been surprised – we thought they’d be next to walk down the aisle. But he wasn’t so sad that he couldn’t put it all aside and celebrate with us on our special day.

You know how, on your wedding day, you don’t leave any detail up to chance? I was like that – from ensuring the table settings didn’t set off anyone’s hay fever to briefing the DJ so everyone heard a song they loved.

I had planned for just about everything

The one thing I didn’t plan for was my mum and Dan both getting looser than I expected and pashing on at table 12.

Being a busy bride on the day, I didn’t get to see what led up to the main event, but once the speeches were made, the first dance was done, and the cake was cut, the dance floor got crowded and everyone had a great time dancing and ripping into the champagne, which was flowing freely.

It was when I decided to leave the dance floor and head to the bar for a top up that my bridesmaid Emma* tried to intercept me.

She looked rattled, and I could tell something was up

My first thought was that Steve was doing something he shouldn’t but I couldn’t even imagine what that could be at his own wedding, so I was staggered by what I saw when I pushed past her.

There they were: Mum straddling Dan on a chair and kissing him like nobody ever wants to see their mother kissing anybody.

I remember at the time being grateful that at least Mum had chosen to buck the mother-of-the-bride tradition and wore pants that day.

I don’t know how long I stood there, gaping with my mouth open, because it felt like time stood still (but my mother continued to writhe on Dan in a way I wish I could forget).

This isn't REALLY happening right?? Source: iStock

Dan spotted me first and broke things up immediately

Then Mum stood up in one swift movement, smoothing her suit and shaking her head as if coming out of a daze.

She walked over and hugged me, whispering into my ear, “It’s your wedding day, darling, don’t make this the thing everyone remembers.”

Even with several champagnes under my belt, I knew she was right.

I didn’t want to cause a scene or make this the one memory everyone took home from the day. I’d waited my whole life to be married and I wasn’t going to let this ruin it.

The rest of the evening passed without incident, although I kept my mother and/or Dan in my line of sight at all times. By the end, I was so exhausted, all I could do was fall into bed and sleep off the strangest day of my life.

Since that day, just over a year ago...

I’ve been much more careful about socialising with my mother. I told her that, even though she hadn’t done anything technically wrong, I felt like she’d disrespected me on my wedding day, and that was something that upset me deeply.

Mum was apologetic, and has sworn that what happened that day with Dan will never happen again, and I believe her. I just don’t really want to be in the same room as the two of them together, feeling the vibe.

For his part, Dan has been utterly unapologetic – brazen, even.

He always asks me how my mum is with a wink and a smile, and as long as he remains single, I’m determined to keep him away from her. A drunken pash at my wedding is one thing, but having my husband’s best mate as my stepdad is way too weird to contemplate.
